subject: Re: [junit] Priority of Assertion?
msgSnippet: Kent, I agree that it is expected behavior, technically. I think you could also make an argument that it would be better if the behavior was different. In my
messageBody:
Kent, I agree that it is expected behavior, technically. I think you
could also make an argument that it would be better if the behavior
was different.

In my view, the behavior is in fact an artifact of an implementation
detail - namely that asserts indicate failures by throwing an
exception. It could be made the case that JUnit "should" report those
failing asserts as failing asserts, not as unexpected exceptions.
Basically, the current behavior masks the true test failure.

Frankly, I have a hunch that the best solution to this problem
actually is to split the test in two, that is, to not mix "expected"
and "assert" in the same test method.

Cheers, Ilja

2008/12/30 kentb <kentb@...>:
> Yosef,
>
> The behavior you describe is what I would expect to see. In the test, you
> declared that an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds exception would be thrown. It was not
> thrown, so the test fails. The error message says that the "wrong" exception
> that was thrown was an AssertionError, which is generated by the
> assertTrue(false). The "expected=..." means that a test can fail if no
> exception is thrown or if the wrong exception is thrown.
>
> Regards,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute

> {
> String s[] = new String[]{"1"};
> assertTrue(false);
> System.out.println(s[10]);
> }
>
> I expect to see an assertion but I see following error:
> java.lang.Exception: Unexpected exception,
> expected<java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException> but
> was<java.lang.AssertionError>..
>
> In your opinion, this test must be Assertion or Exception.
> In "JUnit" we cannot use "@Test(expected = AnyClassException.class")
> and Assertion together at the same time.
> In my opinion this test must be failed for "assertion" and not for
> ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
> Is this a bug in JUnit or my test is wrong and shouldn't use two item
> together?
